meanings.definition: To bark louder or more frequently than (someone or something)
meanings.sent1: The small dog was outbarking the big dog in the park.
meanings.sent2: The neighbor's dog tends to outbark all the other dogs in the neighborhood.
meanings.sent3: The little chihuahua was outbarking the husky, much to everyone's surprise.
meanings.sent4: The enthusiastic puppy seemed to be outbarking the old dog's record for barks per minute.
meanings.sent5: The competition was fierce as each dog tried to outbark the others for the title of 'Loudest Barker'.

meanings.sent1: The energetic puppy managed to outbark all the other dogs at the training session.
meanings.sent2: The howling of the lone wolf could outbark any other sound in the forest.
meanings.sent3: The little terrier was determined to outbark the big shepherd during playtime.
meanings.sent4: The thunderstorm's roar seemed to outbark even the most vocal of dogs in the neighborhood.
meanings.sent5: The challenge was set to see which dog could outbark the others and claim the title of 'Top Barker'.

meanings.sent1: The excited puppy started outbarking as soon as it saw its favorite toy.
meanings.sent2: The old hound would outbark at any noise, no matter how small.
meanings.sent3: The little pug was outbarking at the passing cars, thinking they were intruders.
meanings.sent4: The howling wind seemed to outbark even the most vocal of dogs in the area.
meanings.sent5: The neighborhood was filled with the outbarking of dogs as the mailman made his rounds.
